item.title: The Oxford 2025 Word of the Year Is ‘Rage Bait’
item.description: And if you’re angry about it, that just proves the point.
item.dc:creator: Jennifer Schuessler

item.title: Nashville Closed a Red Grooms Masterpiece. Now the City Wants It Back.
item.description: Art lovers call for the return of a shuttered carousel they say is the casualty of a boomtown razing its own visual heritage.
item.dc:creator: Walker Mimms
item.media:description: Will it ride again? Red Grooms, a Nashvillian by birth, created the Tennessee Fox Trot Carousel — an ode to cultural life and the colorful characters in his hometown--in 1998. By 2003, it had been dismantled. “We were barely even warned it would close,” Grooms recalled. “Spinning one day, then silent the next.”

item.title: Tom Stoppard Wrote Dialogue for Indiana Jones and Obi-Wan Kenobi
item.description: The playwright won an Academy Award for “Shakespeare in Love.” But he was also a prolific script doctor who worked with filmmakers like Steven Spielberg.
item.dc:creator: Eric Grode
item.category: Indiana Jones and the Last Crusade (Movie)
item.media:description: Sean Connery, left, and Harrison Ford during the motorcycle chase scene from the film “Indiana Jones and the Last Crusade.”

item.title: Stream Movies Written by Tom Stoppard: ‘Shakespeare In Love’ and More
item.description: Spinning off Shakespeare, waltzing through Imperial Russia, bantering about literature or diving deeply into history, Stoppard shared his gifts on the screen.
item.dc:creator: Elisabeth Vincentelli

item.title: Review: It’s Hard to Breathe in This ‘Walküre’
item.description: The singers did marvelous work at the Opéra Bastille in Paris, where the director Calixto Bieito’s new staging takes place in a hellish dystopia.
item.dc:creator: Oussama Zahr
item.media:description: In a new production of “Die Walküre,” Wotan builds a surveillance state to hold on to power.

item.title: John Tesh Keeps Bouncing Ba-Ba-Ba-Ba-Ba Back
item.description: The resurgence of “Roundball Rock,” the N.B.A. theme song he composed, has made the musician more visible than he’s been in over 20 years. He hasn’t been idle.
item.dc:creator: Caryn Ganz
item.media:credit: Philip Cheung for The New York Times

item.title: The Beguiling, Misunderstood Theremin
item.description: Invented by accident in the 1920s, the unusual electronic instrument is hard to master but offers an enticing reward: freedom.
item.dc:creator: Carolina Abbott Galvão and Vincent Tullo
item.media:credit: Vincent Tullo for The New York Times

item.title: ‘Stranger Things’ Cast Looks Back on the Show and How It Shaped Them
item.description: The first episodes of the final season just premiered on Netflix. In interviews, the young stars looked back on the show and how it shaped them.
item.dc:creator: Jeremy Egner, Alexis Soloski and Chantal Anderson
item.media:credit: Chantal Anderson for The New York Times

item.title: ‘The Holiday’: A Festive Cocktail, Equal Parts Charm and Cringe
item.description: Cameron Diaz, Kate Winslet, Jude Law and Jack Black delivered a lesson on chemistry, good and bad, in the 2006 Nancy Meyers rom-com.
item.dc:creator: Maya Salam

item.title: Jason Schwartzman Finds Peace at the Library
item.description: “It’s almost like a movie set,” said the actor, now in the Christmas film “Oh. What. Fun.,” “and I have to pretend I’m working, too.”
item.dc:creator: Elisabeth Vincentelli

item.title: The Great Beatles Documentary That’s Nearly Impossible to See (Legally)
item.description: With “The Beatles Anthology” now on Disney+, we dig into “The Compleat Beatles,” another documentary on the band that is difficult to see legally but had an impact on a generation.
item.dc:creator: Jason Bailey
item.media:credit: Brian Randle/Daily Herald and Mirrorpix, via Getty Images
item.media:description: The Beatles during rehearsals for the Royal Variety Performance at the London Palladium in 1963.

item.title: 5 Podcasts to Help You Savor Coffee
item.description: These shows will deepen your appreciation of that next cup of joe, offering detours into coffee house history and tips on how to buy, brew and drink coffee.
item.dc:creator: Emma Dibdin
item.category: Making Coffee with Lucia Solis (Radio Program)

item.title: In ‘The Tale of Silyan,’ the Storks Are Watching
item.description: The birds’ presence lends an otherworldly air to this nonfiction look at a family farm in a dying North Macedonian village.
item.dc:creator: Alissa Wilkinson

item.title: 7 New Movies Our Critics Are Talking About This Week
item.description: Whether you’re a casual moviegoer or an avid buff, our reviewers think these films are worth knowing about.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.category: Wake Up Dead Man: A Knives Out Mystery (Movie)

item.title: ‘Heated Rivalry,’ Plus 8 Things to Watch on TV This Week
item.description: A new show based on a Canadian sports romance novel airs. And a reunion of ‘The Secret Lives of Mormon Wives’ recaps the third season.
item.dc:creator: Shivani Gonzalez
item.media:description: Connor Storrie, left, and Hudson Williams in “Heated Rivarly.”

item.title: ‘It: Welcome to Derry’ Season 1, Episode 6 Recap: Daddy’s Little Girl
item.description: Ingrid’s connection to the evil entity known as It is revealed, among other dangerous secrets.
item.dc:creator: Sean T. Collins
item.media:description: It turns out Ingrid (Madeline Stowe) has a clownish side.

item.title: Daniel Woodrell, ‘Country Noir’ Novelist of ‘Winter’s Bone,’ Dies at 72
item.description: His tales of violence and squalor in his native Ozarks had the timeless quality of fables and inspired several movies.
item.dc:creator: Alex Traub
item.media:description: Daniel Woodrell in 2007. “He writes high Greek tragedy about low people, and he never panders or looks down on the people he writes about,” the writer Dennis Lehane said.

item.title: Biyouna, Algerian Star With Tart Tongue Onscreen and Off, Dies at 73
item.description: For generations of Algerians, the fierce independence of her persona reflected their struggles in a country torn by civil war and repression.
item.dc:creator: Adam Nossiter
item.media:credit: Eric Fougere/VIP Images, via Getty Images
item.media:description: Biyouna in 2015. She was a hero in the working-class Algiers neighborhoods from which she had sprung.

item.title: Glenn Close, Ethan Hawke and Others Mourn Tom Stoppard
item.description: Nobody advanced or cherished the English language more than Stoppard, Tim Curry noted. Colleagues and fans agreed.
item.dc:creator: Jesse Green, Michael Paulson and Laura Collins-Hughes
item.media:credit: Don Hogan Charles/The New York Times
item.media:description: Tom Stoppard with Jeremy Irons and Glenn Close, who both starred in the 1984 Broadway production of the playwright’s “The Real Thing.”

item.title: When Tom Stoppard Confronted His Background in His Final Play ‘Leopoldstadt’
item.description: The playwright, who learned about his Jewish heritage late in life, addressed it in the Tony Award-winning drama “Leopoldstadt.”
item.dc:creator: Marc Tracy
item.media:description: Tom Stoppard, at right at the microphone, accepting the Tony Award for best play in 2023.

item.title: Beyond Art Basel Miami Beach, a Lesson in Cuban American History Awaits
item.description: Visitors to the fair will find a city overflowing with history and art, including contemporary graffiti and posthumous museum retrospectives.
item.dc:creator: Farah Nayeri

item.title: Headed to Art Basel Miami Beach? Here’s What to Know.
item.description: Here are some tips on navigating the largest Art Basel fair in the United States, which will bring together 283 galleries from around the world.
item.dc:creator: Paulette Perhach

item.title: Jack Pierson in Miami: An Artist and a City in Transformation
item.description: Visits to the area in the 1980s left a lasting impression on the artist and his work.
item.dc:creator: Hilarie M. Sheets
item.category: Bass Museum of Art (Miami Beach, Fla)
item.media:credit: Scott McIntyre for The New York Times

item.title: The Language of Tom Stoppard, Ablaze With Energy and Urgency
item.description: In works like “Travesties” and “Arcadia,” the playwright embraced the really big questions and wrestled words into coherent, exhilarating shape.
item.dc:creator: Ben Brantley
item.media:credit: Charlie Gates for The New York Times
item.media:description: Tom Stoppard, in 2022, photographed at his home in Dorset, England.

item.title: The Grand Ole Opry Toasts 100 Years and Considers What’s Next
item.description: A hundred years after it first went live, Nashville’s famed country music show celebrated its history with a series of performances.
item.dc:creator: Emily Cochrane

item.title: Tom Stoppard, Award-Winning Playwright of Witty Drama, Dies at 88
item.description: Drawing comparisons to the greatest of dramatists, he entwined erudition with imagination in stage works that won accolades on both sides of the Atlantic.
item.dc:creator: Bruce Weber
item.media:credit: Fred R. Conrad/The New York Times
item.media:description: Tom Stoppard in 1992. He earned a reputation as the most cerebral of contemporary English-language playwrights, venturing into vast fields of scholarly inquiry.

item.title: What’s on Your Best-Of List for 2025? We Want to Know.
item.description: Best change to your evening routine? Best popcorn seasoning? Best overheard conversation? Tell us your super-subjective, idiosyncratic favorites from the past year.
item.dc:creator: Melissa Kirsch

item.title: ‘Hamilton’ Has Had Quite a Run: An Artist Looks Back
item.description: Our cartoonist had no idea the Broadway musical he scored tickets to in 2015 would become a cultural phenomenon — and an enduring reminder of battles to be fought.
item.dc:creator: Mike Dawson

item.title: For Detectives on TV, the Messiest Case Is Often at Home
item.description: Why do we rarely see them leave work to take the kids to baseball practice? Some of it has to do with the nature of police work, but a tortured back story adds intrigue.
item.dc:creator: Sopan Deb
item.category: Homicide: Life on the Street (TV Program)
item.media:description: Mark Ruffalo with Fabien Frankel in the HBO series “Task.” As with a lot of television investigators, Ruffalo plays an F.B.I. agent whose home life is unraveling as he works a big case.

item.title: Ellen Bryant Voigt, Poet With a Musical Ear, Dies at 82
item.description: Her nine volumes included “Kyrie,” a suite of sonnets about the 1918 influenza epidemic. She was also Pulitzer Prize finalist and a poet laureate of Vermont.
item.dc:creator: Richard Sandomir
item.media:credit: John D. & Catherine T. MacArthur Foundation
item.media:description: Ellen Bryant Voigt in 2015 at her home in Cabot, Vt. She was the state’s poet laureate for four years.

item.title: Five Action Movies to Stream Now
item.description: This month’s picks include elaborate ambulance chasing, a killer shark and crime south of the border.
item.dc:creator: Robert Daniels

item.title: At Tate Britain’s Turner and Constable Show, You Don’t Have to Pick Sides
item.description: J.M.W. Turner and John Constable were fueled by competition, but united by a common wonder at nature’s beauty.
item.dc:creator: Emily LaBarge

item.title: Three Great Documentaries to Stream
item.description: In this month’s picks, a portrait of a vanguard filmmaker, a look back at a televised clash between writers, and a reflection on a Hollywood star and pinup.
item.dc:creator: Ben Kenigsberg

item.title: Louvre Raising Ticket Prices for Non-European Visitors
item.description: From Jan. 14, visitors to the museum from outside the European Economic Area will pay 45 percent more for entry to help finance its ambitious renovation plan.
item.dc:creator: Ségolène Le Stradic and Alex Marshall
item.media:credit: Dmitry Kostyukov for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Louvre is still on the mend after thieves broke into one of its galleries in October and stole about $100 million worth of jewelry.

item.title: Ruth Thorne-Thomsen, Photographer of Dreamlike Tableaux, Dies at 82
item.description: Using a pinhole camera, she captured miniature landscapes that she had fashioned to resemble surreal versions of 19th-century travel photos.
item.dc:creator: Penelope Green
item.media:description: Ruth Thorne-Thomsen in an undated photo. When a friend gave her a pinhole camera in graduate school, “I knew immediately that this was it,” she said. “It was the blueprint, the matrix, for everything that followed.”

item.title: At New York City Ballet’s ‘Nutcracker,’ Bring on Fritz and Brat Winter
item.description: At New York City Ballet, two boys from the School of American Ballet get to play a coveted role: Fritz, a terror of a little brother.
item.dc:creator: Gia Kourlas and Thea Traff
item.category: Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts
item.media:credit: Thea Traff for The New York Times

item.title: How a Rediscovered Klimt Got Swept Up in an International Dispute
item.description: The Viennese painter’s portrait of a West African prince was owned by a Jewish family who fled the Nazi occupation. It was then taken to Hungary, which has now moved to block a sale by an Austrian gallery.
item.dc:creator: Scott Reyburn
item.media:credit: Marcel Van Hoorn/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: The Gustav Klimt painting of Prince William Nii Nortey Dowuona on display earlier this year.

item.title: Robert A.M. Stern, Architect Who Reinvented Prewar Splendor, Dies at 86
item.description: He designed museums, schools and libraries before winning international acclaim late in life for 15 Central Park West in Manhattan, hailed as a rebirth of the luxury apartment building.
item.dc:creator: Robert D. McFadden
item.media:description: Robert A.M. Stern in 2007. Glowing reviews drove a stampede of celebrities to 15 CPW — the building he described as “my breakthrough” — overshadowing the competition from sleek glass towers that had been the rage in Manhattan early in the new millennium.

item.title: ‘Blossoms Shanghai’ Review: In the Mood for Commerce
item.description: Wong Kar-wai’s first TV series, streaming on the Criterion Channel, is a lush melodrama about an economic miracle.
item.dc:creator: Mike Hale
item.media:description: Hu Ge stars as the Gatsby-like protagonist of “Blossoms Shanghai,” the first television series from Wong Kar-wai.

item.title: 5 Years After His Death, John Prine Gets a Cinematic Send-Off
item.description: The singer and songwriter died in April 2020 of Covid-19, delaying proper tributes. Now he is the subject of a new documentary, “You Got Gold.”
item.dc:creator: Bob Mehr
item.category: You Got Gold: A Celebration of John Prine (Movie)
item.media:description: John Prine in 1975. A profound sense of intimacy was the hallmark of his work.

item.title: A Guide to NYC Holiday Events: Rockefeller Tree Lighting, Ice Skating and More
item.description: Matinees, ice skating and train shows: Here are some of our favorite things to do this season.
item.dc:creator: Michaela Towfighi
item.media:description: The reveal of Saks Fifth Avenue’s holiday light show and windows on Monday, Nov. 24.

item.title: ‘You Got Gold: A Celebration of John Prine’ Review: Paying Tribute in Nashville
item.description: Lyle Lovett, Bonnie Raitt, Kacey Musgraves and other luminaries perform Prine’s songs in this engaging concert film.
item.dc:creator: Glenn Kenny

item.title: ‘The Thing With Feathers’ Review: Parenting Without Your Better Half
item.description: A grieving father struggles to care for his two children after the death of his wife. Even with its star, Benedict Cumberbatch, the movie never takes flight.
item.dc:creator: Lisa Kennedy

item.title: ‘The Stringer: The Man Who Took the Photo’ Review: Freelancing Woes
item.description: Was a freelance photographer intentionally left out of the famous Vietnam War photo of “Napalm Girl”?
item.dc:creator: Beatrice Loayza
item.category: The Stringer: The Man Who Took the Photo (Movie)

item.title: ‘Left-Handed Girl’ Review: An Electric Portrait of Taipei
item.description: The filmmaker Shih-Ching Tsou tells a sensitive story of a mother and her two daughters struggling to get by in Taiwan.
item.dc:creator: Natalia Winkelman

item.title: ‘BLKNWS: Terms & Conditions’ Review: An Artist’s Mind-Expanding Collage
item.description: In this dazzling essay movie, the director Kahlil Joseph draws on an array of sources — news clips, old movies, family albums, an encyclopedia of ”Africana” — to create a thrilling whole.
item.dc:creator: Manohla Dargis

item.title: 3 Cozy Books We Love
item.description: Pick up a mug of tea, grab a blanket and settle down to read. Jennifer Harlan, an editor at The New York Times Book Review, recommends three books that are perfect for cozy fall reading.
item.dc:creator: Jennifer Harlan, Karen Hanley, Claire Hogan and Laura Salaberry

item.title: Jimmy Fallon Gets Into the Spirit of ‘Drinksgiving’
item.description: “’Twas the night before Thanksgiving, and in your parents’ house, they put the Peloton in your old bedroom, so you’re sleeping on the couch,” Fallon mused.
item.dc:creator: Trish Bendix
item.category: Late Night with Seth Meyers (TV Program)

item.title: Tiny Love Stories: ‘No Hugging … and Definitely Nothing Lewd’
item.description: Modern Love in miniature, featuring reader-submitted stories of no more than 100 words.

item.title: Broadway Performers Rehearse for the Macy’s Thanksgiving Day Parade
item.description: We tagged along to a late-night rehearsal for performers from “Just in Time,” “Buena Vista Social Club” and “Ragtime.”
item.dc:creator: Erik Piepenburg and Dolly Faibyshev
item.media:credit: Dolly Faibyshev for The New York Times

item.title: A Speedy Art-Career Rise Fueled by a Descent Into Our Modern Abyss
item.description: Contemporary life, speculative fiction, Asian futurism and social documentary all meet in Ayoung Kim’s videos at MoMA PS1. And are they fun to watch!
item.dc:creator: Martha Schwendener

item.title: ‘The Secret Agent’ Review: Wagner Moura Is on the Run
item.description: Wagner Moura takes cover in this knockout from the filmmaker Kleber Mendonça Filho that is largely set in 1977 during Brazil’s miliary dictatorship.
item.dc:creator: Manohla Dargis

item.title: Apple TV Series ‘The Hunt’ Is Pulled Amid Accusations of Plagiarism
item.description: Apple TV postponed the launch of the French-language series following accusations that its creator copied key elements from a 1973 novel.
item.dc:creator: Jenny Gross
item.media:description: The French screenwriter Cédric Anger, who wrote “The Hunt,” pictured in Los Angeles in October.

item.title: A Therapist’s Advice on How to Navigate the Holiday Season With Family
item.description: Family holidays can be stressful. They don’t have to be.
item.dc:creator: Anna Martin

item.title: How Jane Austen Fans Are Celebrating Her 250th Birthday
item.description: For Janeites around the globe, the 250th anniversary of the English author’s birth is cause for elaborate celebrations.
item.dc:creator: Sarah Lyall
item.category: Austen, Jane, Society of North America
Jane Austen Society of the United Kingdom
item.media:credit: Peter Flude for The New York Times

item.title: Fatherhood on Film: Dad Is Having a Rough Time Onscreen This Season
item.description: In films like “One Battle After Another,” “Springsteen” and “Ella McCay,” patriarchs are depicted as emotionally stunted or worse.
item.dc:creator: Clarissa Cruz

item.title: ‘Zootopia 2’ Review: Natural Habitats, Expanded
item.description: A sequel to the 2016 hit, this movie about an animal metropolis takes on an even messier social allegory than the first one, while building out a wider (if bloated) universe.
item.dc:creator: Brandon Yu

item.title: ‘Teenage Wasteland’ Review: Young in Age, Mature in Reporting
item.description: This documentary looks back at a group of teenagers who, in the early 1990s, created a high school video project that ended up breaking real news.
item.dc:creator: Ben Kenigsberg

item.title: ‘Hamnet’ Review: The Rest Is Silence
item.description: Jessie Buckley and Paul Mescal star in a heartbreaking adaptation of the best-selling novel.
item.dc:creator: Alissa Wilkinson

item.title: ‘Eternity’ Review: Dead Reckoning
item.description: Elizabeth Olsen plays a dead woman who must choose her forever partner in this silly afterlife rom-com.
item.dc:creator: Jeannette Catsoulis

item.title: ‘Wake Up Dead Man: A Knives Out Mystery’ Review: Forgive Them, Father
item.description: Josh O’Connor leads a star-studded cast in the latest Benoit Blanc mystery — this one, about religious cults of personality.
item.dc:creator: Alissa Wilkinson
item.category: Wake Up Dead Man: A Knives Out Mystery (Movie)
